MissionCommands.Message: Welcome back, {{profileName}}. In this lesson we will go through all the steps required to launch, the procedures needed during the ascent, and what to monitor as the rocket lifts off.
From now on, I recommend you complete each of the academy lessons twice. Once to get an overview, and twice to build on that overview.
The ascent is an automated process and your main task is to monitor the instruments periodically while being prepared for an abort, or to take over control manually.
We are currently 20 minutes away from ignition, with plenty of excess time to go over some details.

However, just to be sure, I will teach you how to hold the countdown manually. Press the [C] button to toggle the function bubbles located on the right side, just below the green section of the panels.
Locate and find the HOLD COUNTDOWN function bubble, and click it.
Excellent, the countdown is now holding.
The cockpit panels are in their final pre-launch configuration, with only a few remaining switches to be adjusted.
Let's open the MISSION PAD. Press [M] to toggle it, and then press the CHECKLISTS tab. Press ROGER when you have it open.

The CHECKLIST tab of the MISSION PAD contains all the Mercury checklists needed during a mission. We currently have two checklists to complete before we can ascend: the FULL INTERNAL POWER and the FINAL CHECKS.

This lesson will take you through all of the required steps so you can press [M] to toggle the Mission Pad off again. In the next lesson, we will learn more about it, and some features of the checklist system that allow it to help us execute checklists.
We are currently holding the countdown but typically, at around 10 minutes before liftoff, often referred to as T -10 minutes, the power source is switched from external power to internal power.
The rocket is currently receiving power through an umbilical connected to the launch pad. This is to avoid consuming power from the internal power system (batteries) before the mission even starts.
Take a look at the panels in front of you, and try to locate the DC AMPS gauge. It is on the right side of the periscope. Press ROGER to highlight it.
This is the DC AMPS gauge. It shows the current consumption of the internal power system in amps.
On the left side of the DC AMPS gauge you can find the DC VOLTS gauge.
This shows the DC VOLTS of the internal power system.
Below the two gauges you can find the DC selector. This is used to select what bus the DC VOLTS and DC AMPS gauge is measuring. Set this to 1 by left clicking on it.
The DC AMPS and DC VOLTS gauge now shows the voltage of battery 1 and the current load on battery 1.

The blockhouse (a house that controls the launch located on the current launch complex) will soon switch to internal power. During the power transition, it is important to monitor the DC AMPS and DC VOLTS gauge.
Set the DC SELECTOR back to M by right clicking on it once. This monitors the capsule's main electrical bus (more on this in the electrical power system lesson).
Now, observe the DC AMPS and DC VOLTS while pressing ROGER to let the blockhouse know you are ready to switch to internal power.
Excellent. The Main bus is now handling the load from all the on-board equipment. The Main bus voltage should be around 23-27 volts with a consumption of 20 - 40 amps.
You have now checked the MAIN bus voltage and loads. Let's check the load of battery 1. Set the DC SELECTOR to 1. This selects Battery 1.
It should read about 23-27 volts and amps 10 - 20. Check battery No. 2 as well.
Okay, it should also read about 23-27 volts and amps 10 - 20. Check battery No. 3 as well.
The SBY 1, SBY 2 and ISO currently have no load, so amps should be zero. However, they should have volts. Let's check. Set the DC SELECTOR to SBY 1.
SBY 1 stands for Standby Battery 1, one of our two backup system batteries. Check that its voltage is between 23 and 27 volts, then set the DC SELECTOR to SBY 2.
SBY 2 stands for Standby Battery 2, one of our two backup system batteries. Check that its voltage is between 23 and 27 volts. Then set the DC SELECTOR to ISO.

ISO stands for Isolated Battery and is mainly used to power something called the SQUIBs. We will cover the SQUIBs later. For now, ensure that the ISOlated battery has a voltage of 29 vdc. Set the DC SELECTOR back to MAIN.

Excellent, we have now made a full electrical bus check after the switch to internal power, and everything is looking good. This is also something you need to do periodically during the ascent, preferably every 30 seconds.
The "Switch to Full Internal Power" should happen 10 minutes before ignition to avoid excess consumption of mission critical battery power. We do not want to run out of power in space!
I will now teach you how to RESUME the COUNTDOWN again. Press [C] to toggle the function bubbles and locate the RESUME COUNTDOWN button, then press it to resume the countdown.
You can use the alpha keys to time scale. Next we will use the [1] (normal time) ,[2] (2x time scale), [3] (5x time scale), etc. to timescale to T -5 minutes before launch.

You typically use time scale to reduce waiting time. The feature is available during a mission except during powered or critical mission phases such as ascent and reentry. You can always press [0] to pause the game. Try to set timescale to 2x by pressing [2], then [1] to return.
Time scale to T -5 minutes. Avoid using more than [5] (20x time scale) on the launch pad as you might miss important steps.
I have now made an automatic HOLD of the countdown to ensure we have enough time.
It's time to perform the FINAL CHECKs needed to complete the pre-launch capsule configurations, which will make us ready for the ascent.

Let's signal to the Blockhouse that we are starting the final checks and will be ready for launch. Set the LAUNCH CONTROL switch to READY so the blockhouse knows they can trigger the ignition. If this switch is READY, the rocket will launch when the countdown reaches zero.
Check that the SUIT TEMP selector is set to position 3 (a triangle MARKS this default ascent position).
Check that the CABIN TEMP selector is set to position 3 as well (again, a triangle MARKS this default ascent position).
Check that the INVERTER TEMP selector is set to position 3 as well (again, a triangle MARKS this default ascent position).
Then, ensure TRANSMIT is set to UHF.
With the TRANSMIT switch set to UHF, make a RADIO CHECK by pressing [C] to toggle the function bubbles and pressing the RADIO CHECK button. Press ROGER when you have pressed this button.
Left click once on the TIME ZERO button to remove the cover, but do not press the button (the button will be pressed if you click it again after removing the cover).
During ascent, depending on the Launch Vehicle, you will go through different stages to reach the velocity required for a mission. The SQUIB bus needs to be ARMED for this, so ARM the SQUIBS!
ARM the AUTO RETRO JETTISON squib. This is a special SQUIB used to jettison our retrograde engines (more on this later) which needs to be armed in case of an abort.
Excellent, we are now ready for the ascent! Before we continue with the countdown, let's go through the ascent procedures.
The Redstone ascent is about 2 minutes and 30 seconds. Before the ignition, you will hear the countdown. This will count down to liftoff.
After this, the engines should be ignited and the rocket will start to climb.
Immediately after lift-off, we need to first monitor that the mission timer starts. If it does not, you need to quickly press the TIME ZERO button to manually start the timer.
The TIME FROM LAUNCH timer is the mission timer, and is located below the analogue clock on the Satellite Clock.
Then you should check that you are gaining altitude. You can use the Altitude gauge to check altitude during ascent and landing.
Once you start gaining altitude, immediately monitor the TIME FROM LAUNCH clock to verify that it has in fact started, and is still counting.

The ABORT light on top of the sequencer panel needs to be monitored continuously (as best as you can). If it is illuminated, immediately toggle an ABORT by pulling the abort handle. You can pull the handle by pressing [CTRL]+[ALT]+[Z]. Press ROGER when you have found the ABORT light.

During the climb, use the window to ensure visually that you are heading upwards or along the horizon. Cycle through the various gauges quickly and often. I know there are a lot of instruments, but these are vital for a safe ascent. Let me cover the most important ones.
The Capsule has two Fuel Tanks: one for the autopilot, and another for manual control. The CONTROL FUEL indicator should stay at 100% for both AUTO (left) and MANUAL (right) during the entire ascent.
Above the fuel gauge you will find the accelerometer. G-forces will build up when accelerating. This will usually climb up to 5 or 6 during the ascent, and as high as 12-16 during reentry.

The cabin is now fully pressurized with pure oxygen at sea level pressure. The pressure will bleed off over time. Ensure this decreases, and stabilizes at 5.5 PSIA during the ascent. The Environmental Control System (ECS) will maintain cabin pressure at 5.5. This can be seen on the CABIN PRESSURE gauge.

The Pitch Program will automatically pitch the rocket along the ascent path. Ensure this happens by checking the pitch needle on the attitude indicator. It will move from 90 towards 0, depending on mission profile.
The capsule has two oxygen tanks: one primary and one secondary. The ECS controls them automatically. When the primary tank is empty (less than 10%) it will switch to the secondary tank.
Ensure the oxygen levels are 100% during ascent. If they bleed off fast or seem strange, diagnose and abort. You have enough oxygen to breathe for about 24 hours.
A healthy battery shows 24 volts. As we did during the internal power electrical check, select what battery to monitor using the DC selector.
The DC volts on the selected system will be visible on the DC VOLTS gauge. Cycle through the volts of all the batteries too to ensure they are all above 24.
Check that the ALTITUDE continues to increase when you are below 100 thousand feet. Again, it is important to monitor this right after liftoff to ensure you are climbing.

Check the cabin air temperature, which is measured in Fahrenheit. If it's too cold or too warm, adjust the temperature settings knob below the hatch (rightmost panel). Never exceed 120F in either of the circuits.

The Sequencer indicators to the left of the main panel will glow based on what stage you are in. White (unlit) means that it's not processing, orange means it's processing (or something is in need of attention), and green means the step is complete.
If you have done everything correctly, the rocket should be ready for ignition.

Let's review one more time. At lift-off, verify that the clock is started and that you are increasing in altitude. Then monitor the abort light as you cycle through the G-forces, fuel levels, cabin pressure, total oxygen quantity, and main bus DC volts.
I have now resumed the countdown. If you need more time, feel free to hold and resume manually. Use time scale to liftoff.
30 seconds to ignition. Godspeed, {profileName}.
Lift-off! Immediately check if the timer is counting.
Then verify that the rocket is gaining altitude.

Use the window to ensure visually that you are heading upwards or slowly pitching towards the horizon. For the rest of the ascent, monitor the key instruments. Let's take a quick look around together.
Check that both fuel tanks, AUTO and MANUAL, are at 100%.
Check G-Forces, which should climb up to 6 g's.
Check that cabin pressure is bleeding and eventually stops at 5.5 psia.
Monitor the pitch program. The rocket should slowly align itself towards the horizon.
Check the total amount of oxygen (O2).
Check the MAIN DC BUS, and rotate the DC SELECTOR fully every 30 seconds while checking all the batteries, then return it back to MAIN.
Check the altitude.
Check cabin air temperature, and verify it's below 120 degrees F.
Monitor the sequencer lights for JETT TOWER and SEP CAPSULE to turn green.
Repeat this cycle during the ascent.
Once the tower is jettisoned and the capsule is separated, the ascent is complete. After the ascent, the capsule will yaw 180 degrees, and position you in a normal orbital attitude automatically.
Excellent, great job today. I recommend rehearsing ascents using the Redstone Free Flight mission. And bonus points to you if you managed to detect that the 3rd battery failed during the ascent.
Awesome, good job, this concludes the ascent lesson.

Title: Tutorial 2 - Launch & Ascent
Description: In this lesson we will go through all the steps required for launch and ascent! Luckily, the ascent is an automated process, but emergencies can happen so your task is to monitor all of the gauges periodically while being prepared for an abort.
BriefingText:
BRIEFING

In this lesson we will go through all the steps required for launch and the ascent! Luckily, the ascent is an automated process, but emergencies can happen. Your task is to monitor all of the gauges periodically while being prepared for an abort.
